title: 105_s2100
content: The Act may be cited as the "Campus Crime Disclosure Act of 1998". The findings of Congress highlight that 63 institutions of higher education have violated the Crime Awareness and Campus Security Act of 1990 without facing punitive action. The Department of Education's interpretation of campus definitions has led to underreporting of crimes against students. Congress aims to clarify the law and discourage underreporting to improve public awareness of crimes on college campuses. Congress aims to clarify the law and discourage underreporting to improve public awareness of crimes on college campuses by adding additional crime categories. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include statistics on criminal offenses reported on college campuses, including murder, sex offenses, robbery, assault, burglary, and motor vehicle theft. This amendment aims to improve public awareness of crimes on college campuses. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include statistics on criminal offenses reported on college campuses, such as murder, sex offenses, robbery, assault, burglary, motor vehicle theft, manslaughter, larceny, arson, liquor law violations, drug-related violations, and weapons violations. Subparagraphs are adjusted and amended for clarity and consistency. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to ensure that reports on criminal offenses on college campuses are easily accessible to students and employees through various mediums. Additionally, the definition of campus is clarified. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to clarify the definition of a campus, including buildings owned or controlled by the institution, student organizations, and public property within the same geographic area. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to define a campus as including buildings, student residential facilities, and public property providing immediate access to facilities owned or controlled by the institution. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include reporting requirements. Section 485(f) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require reporting non-compliant institutions to Congress and providing assistance for those struggling with reporting requirements. In accordance with paragraph (1)(F), higher education institutions must categorize criminal offenses and disciplinary referrals based on where they occur on campus, including sidewalks, streets, parking facilities, dormitories, and affiliated facilities. SEC. 7. FINES. Section 485(f) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Secretary to impose a civil penalty of up to $25,000 on institutions of higher education for violations, failures, or misrepresentations. The Secretary has the authority to compromise the penalty amount. The Secretary can impose a civil penalty of up to $25,000 on institutions of higher education for violations, failures, or misrepresentations. The penalty amount can be adjusted based on the size of the institution and the severity of the violation. The penalty can be deducted from any sums owed by the institution to the United States.
